channel.name: Oracle L1 on-chain price feed architecture - impossible?

messages.content:
It’s my current understanding that a price feed managed through on-chain state wouldn’t work with L1 mina. 

If you have an oracle contract that maintains the price as state, then any transaction that updates that state would invalidate any transactions that depend on that state within the same block. 

With a price feed in particular, it is important that the price data remain fresh i.e. you would want to be able to update that as frequently as possible, especially in the event of volatility. Any system depending on this price feed contract would be rendered effectively useless.

Therefore we must generate the price data off-chain and verify on-chain. Does anyone know of any good design patterns here that could improve robustness and decentralisation rather than some single entity simply signing the data?

I don’t know that a price feed on L1 is impossible if we can speed the chain up by some factor.  Like would 30 second block time be too slow?

Or what if you wrap 10 eth blocks with pricing data and write the min, max, median, and average over the range?
I think whatever time scale you come up with, you can imagine a scenario one microsecond faster, so it’s kind of an arbitrary cutoff of what we consider “fast enough”.

I understand your argument and agree with you to a certain extent. For me it’s not necessarily the frequency of the updates rather than the fact that when it’s updated it will invalidate any transaction that has used it as a precondition when processed in that block. 

Chainlinks model is to have a deviation threshold and a heartbeat. The price will update via a transaction when it has moved from its deviation threshold or when the heartbeat time has elapsed, whichever is sooner. On their ETH/USD feed the heartbeat is 1 hour, and the deviation threshold is set to 0.5%. In times of higher volatility the price can be updated every couple of minutes. 

For sake of argument, lets say in times of lowish volatility the price is updated once every 30 mins. Operating within the custom systems parameters, that still means that 10% of the time, users transactions would fail because their price precondition has been invalidated. And in times of higher volatility, lets say once every 6 minutes, half of all transactions would fail the precondition. Do you think that is acceptable user experience within the system?

Maybe its not about the latency of the price as much as it is the transaction fail rate with a L1 design. For example, if you sped the block time up to 1 second blocks, and then we updated the price every 100 seconds, you would have 1% of transactions that would fail due to the precondition failure. One might argue that fail rate is acceptable. What do you think?
It can be solved easily by using token accounts for writing price data with the time and having the last token account address in main contract state.

What is the logic about 10% of transactions failing or 50% of transactions failing?  What precondition are you referencing?  In general, it sounds like that could be fixed by setting the precondition to a range.  The user can say what range they are comfortable with and the transaction will only fail if the price moves by more than their tolerance.

In the case of the token accounts, 0% of the txs will fail, and the tolerance can be set to 0. The cost of 1 MINA per token account can be solved by rotating 10-20 token accounts, limiting the total cost.

I'm talking about the price held in an oracle contract. If I have transactions in contracts that `getAndRequireEquals` the price state on the oracle contract. If that price is updated in the same block that the transaction is processed that uses it as a precondition, then wont the transaction fail?
Interesting. Can you please explain/elaborate more on this for me? Or point me to somewhere where I can look into it further?

It is similar to the technology used by Mina Domain Names
https://github.com/Staketab/mina-names/blob/main/contracts/src/contract/domain-contract.ts

When you put the new price point to the contract, you create a new token account (or reuse the old one that was not used for the last 10 or 20 price points) and put to the 8 Fields of this account the information about the price and the time when this price was written, maybe with the pointer to the previous price point.
At the same time, you put the PublicKey of this token account to the state of the main contract, which should be TokenContract.

When you consume price information, you fetch the last price point PublicKey of the token account from the main contract and use it in your tx. It will not change, and the price will not change even if the state of the main contract is updated by writing new price points and creating new token accounts. To ensure that the price is not outdated, you put some expiry time to the price point to ensure that the price information stored on the token account will expire at some time.
P.S. Expiry does not work on Zeko at the moment; it only works on Mina.

A simpler version would be to write eight last price points to the state of the main contract and check that the price point used in your tx is equal to at least one of those points, it is similar to how actions hash is compared with the last five values in Actions and Reducer.

Yeah the idea of setting a tolerance doesn't work with on chain state either.  You need to assert the exact state, otherwise the prover would be able to adjust the state value used in the proof by as much as the tolerance and still make a valid proof.
Fascinating solution, I'm going to dive into this.
Please note that if your price point is UInt64, you can pack 31 UInt64 to eight Fields, having 30 price points and 1 pointer to the last price

I'm wondering how I can compare a value to these on-chain price points? 

If I am updating one of those eight price points each block to keep fresh data on chain then the precondition check will be invalidated each block.

For me to actually compare a value to on chain state,  I need to use `getAndRequireEquals` against that state. So even if I am saying "This value needs to equal at least one of these price points",  as I have updated one of the price points in that block then one of the precondition checks will fail, invalidating the transaction.
You call getAndRequireEquals only against one Field and can update others without problems.
It will not work, you can just conditionally choose values, but you cannot conditionally execute code

Yeah thats right, but I can conditionally attach an AccountUpdate to the transaction. So the question is, why am I getting the `Update_not_permitted_app_state` when that account update is being created from within the smart contract method.

The associated text with an account update `create` reads:

```
    /**
     * Creates an account update. If this is inside a transaction, the account
     * update becomes part of the transaction. If this is inside a smart contract
     * method, the account update will not only become part of the transaction,
     * but also becomes available for the smart contract to modify, in a way that
     * becomes part of the proof.
     */
```

So surely that account update becomes part of the proof, and as I have the default permission: `editState: Permissions.proof()` it should allow that update to succeed?
How can you conditionally attach an AccountUpdate to the transaction inside the method?
https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js/blob/main/src/lib/mina/account-update.ts#L1094

embeds.title: o1js/src/lib/mina/account-update.ts at main · o1-labs/o1js
embeds.description: TypeScript framework for zk-SNARKs and zkApps. Contribute to o1-labs/o1js development by creating an account on GitHub.

messages.content:
Simpler solution would be to split updatePrice to updatePriceOdd and updatePriceEven and just check isOdd value inside both, and then to decide which one to call at the tx creation time.

Or, you can always set both updateEven.body.update.appState[0] and updateEven.body.update.appState[1], just you will set one of those to old values
yeah nice one, totally had a brain fart that I couldn't just `getAndRequireEquals` both of those values cause this is the only place we update them.
